outputs.output_descr:
UN Theme Group on HIV/AIDS continuously supports national AIDS authority, develops and implements national monitoring and evaluation system, harmonizes and coordinates cosponsors' response and scales up functional partnership between all partners with the main objective of contributing to the development of HIV/AIDS policy in the country.
Three main pillars include:
1.	Supporting National AIDS Commission in implementing National AIDS Strategy
2.	Strengthening HIV/AIDS Surveillance; nationally and regionally 
3.	Human Rights
Donors: 
Co-sponsors' contributions (UNICEF, UNHCR, UNDP and WHO) and UNAIDS Programme Acceleration Funds 
Partners: 
Ministry of Health and Social Welfare
National Public Health Institute
Coordination of National HIV/AIDS program implementing agencies
UNAIDS Co-sponsors
International development agencies and NGOs

The WHO Collaborating Centre for Capacity Building in HIV/AIDS Surveillance is a unique centre which brings together an interdisciplinary group of scientists and policy makers across the University of Zagreb and institutions of excellence in HIV surveillance from all over the world. 
The Centre mission is to contribute to increasing capacities in the implementation of effective, sustainable and context-specific HIV surveillance and monitoring and evaluation systems which enable evidence-based development of HIV prevention, care and treatment.
The Centre is based at the Andrija Štampar School of Public Health, Medical School, University of Zagreb. Sharing knowledge and building research capacities are the key components of Centre's work. 
Since the Centre establishment in 2003, more than 875 professionals from 64 countries in Europe, North and Central Africa and the Middle East have been trained in HIV surveillance and monitoring and evaluation.
The Centre is committed to helping countries to develop strategic information to guide a more effective HIV/AIDS response by providing innovative training programmes and technical assistance, as well as developing partnerships and collaborative networks that bring together a wide range of expertise in the field.
The Centre was established as a Knowledge Hub in 2003 under the framework of the Project "Capability Strengthening for Improved Utilization of Financial Resources to Fight HIV/AIDS" and funded by the Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ) and WHO EURO. 
UNDP has been providing administrative and organisational support to the Centre since 2005.
The central objective of this project was to support countries in the optimal access to and use of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria (GFATM) and other large grants through supporting the development of local technical capacity in launching large-scale responses to HIV/AIDS. The Knowledge Hub was designated the WHO Collaborating Centre for Capacity Building in HIV/AIDS Surveillance in March 2008. 
Capacity building and technical assistance to countries to develop effective HIV/AIDS surveillance are main areas of work. 
Specifically, the Knowledge Hub provides 18 different training modules in HIV/AIDS surveillance along with development of new training modules and teaching materials, and consultancies to the countries in development and implementation of HIV/AIDS surveillance.
